p: In the second temporal segment of the study (December 1, 2021 to September 30, 2022), when the Omicron variant of COVID-19 was prevalent, vaccination against COVID-19 was associated with reduced rates of venous thromboembolism [7 days: 3.6% vs 8.0%; HR = 0.44; 95% CI = 0.33–0.60 and 30 days: 4.9% vs 9.2%; HR = 0.52; 95% CI = 0.40–0.68] and acute myocardial infarction [7 days: 4.0% vs 7.7%; HR = 0.51; 95% CI = 0.38–0.69 and 30 days: 4.6% vs 8.2%; HR = 0.55; 95% CI = 0.41–0.72]. There was no association with reduced mortality or intracranial hemorrhage in the vaccinated cohort (Table 3).
